Various Attorneys General have negotiated changes to the 3M proposed $10.3 billion settlement with the nation's water systems. Those changes are reflected in a proposed consent order filed in the MDL - U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina. Those changes are listed as follows: 1. "The uncapped indemnity in favor of 3M, which could have left water systems liable for damages well beyond their expected recovery from the settlement, is removed in its entirety, significantly increasing the value of the settlement to participating water systems; 2. The deadline for eligible water systems to review the settlement and determine whether to opt-out is extended to 90 days; 3. The establishment of a settlement-specific website with information that will allow water systems to derive a good-faith estimate of what they may receive under the 3M settlement agreement if they participate in it (although actual settlement awards will depend on data that is not yet available); and 4. Claims by states and the federal government are expressly carved out of the agreement, allowing for future action and additional settlements against 3M." https://lnkd.in/gmk4dnPH

Federal court okays the 3M Co.'s multibillion dollar settlement with water utilities. The settlement resolves 3M's battles with most water utilities regarding sources of drinking water that have been contaminated with a fire suppressant made for decades with certain PFAS the company produced. But, 3M faces more legal battles continue on the personal injury and other fronts. Meanwhile water utilities--which face imminent national drinking water limits for some PFAS--already are pursing additional funds from companies that made the specialized fire suprressant, aqueous film forming foam (AFFF), with other types of PFAS.
